text: .@Earthjustice attorney David Henkin gives his final thoughts on defending America's clean water in front of the Supreme Court, likely the biggest day of his career. #CleanWaterActIntact https://t.co/b6k9I8nflc
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: At the end, Justice Sotomayor brought it home asking: What current regs exist that stop the county from polluting the ocean? It’s definitely happening, Maui says the Clean Water Act shouldn't stop them, so are they just going to get away with it? What is being done to stop this?
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: Justices generally seemed to reject the County's extreme position that only pollution direct from a point source is regulated, so pollution sprayed through air or that travels over ground would also be free of Clean Water Act regs. But they seemed unsure how far to go.
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: The attorney for the U.S. Government made an analogy about spiking a punch with whiskey. Henkin deftly turned it back around. @Earthjustice’s Sam Sankar explains here. https://t.co/XZrQIjAQM3
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: Justice Sotomayor interjected that’s a problem because it presumes the state will regulate that pollution. Justice Kagan also stated that this case isn’t about relying on state backstops.
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: The County also deflected responsibility back to the states, saying state groundwater permitting, grant programs, etc. are sufficient to regulate pollution that flows from a point source (like Maui County’s wastewater wells) through groundwater and to a protected body of water.
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: For more on the back and forth over the Justice’s questions on limits, see @ellengilmer's story for @environment. https://t.co/VuhxjvH4KM
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: Henkin said pollution that is “traceable” and a “proximate cause” would be regulated and that for 3 decades, @EPA had gone with that interpretation without millions of homeowners on the hook for pollution from their septic tanks.
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: But the Justices also asked @Earthjustice's Henkin: What should be a definition for a limit to what is regulated? Would this interpretation mean homeowners' septic tanks that leach through groundwater to a river need to get permits under the Clean Water Act (or face stiff fines).
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: A few Justices feared the County’s position would create a road map for polluters to evade regulation. Justice Breyer asked: What if we end the pipe 5 ft from the ocean? Justice Kagan doubled down, saying nobody would get a permit if they could cut the pipe a few feet short.
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: The County interpretation of the Clean Water Act is that a “point source” (such as a pipe) MUST be the thing that delivers pollution to water for it to be regulated. Discharge through groundwater or not straight from the “point source,” should not be regulated.
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: We’re out of the hearing for Maui County v. Hawai'i Wildlife Fund. The Justices posed tough questions to both sides. Here are some of the highlights from the hearing. #CleanWaterActIntact https://t.co/THoEqZYiGj
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: Maui County argues that a polluter can avoid the law by taking a pipe that pumps waste into the ocean and cutting it 10 feet short of the shoreline. Waste from the pipeline still pollutes the water. Under the county’s logic, the polluter would get off scot-free.
name: Earthjustice
description: Because the earth needs a good lawyer

text: The case is County of Maui v. Hawai’i Wildlife Fund, in which the county argues that even if pollution from a source reaches a river, lake, or ocean, as long as the source is not directly discharging pollution into that water, it is not regulated by the Clean Water Act.
name: Earthjustice
